awd_titl_txt: Automated Debriefing in Simulation-based Training of Paramedics: Comparing Self-guided to Agent Facilitated Debriefing
awd_abstract_narration:
The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for paramedics and other emergency medical service providers, such as emergency medical technicians (EMTs).  These first responders can keep a person who is struggling to breathe alive until they arrive at a hospital and receive sustained care, including support from a respiratory ventilator if necessary.  This project focuses on paramedics, who have the highest level of training in pre-hospital care.  In addition to utilizing airway devices that support breathing, paramedics can revive a heart attack victim, deliver a baby who cannot wait for his/her mother to get to the hospital, administer medications, and perform other life-sustaining procedures.  Unfortunately, there is a critical shortage of paramedics in many parts of the US, which is partly due to student failure from paramedic training programs, or inability to pass state and national certification exams.  This project will develop a handheld tablet device that will allow small groups of paramedic students to get extra practice in performing pre-hospital care procedures on patient manikins.  These supplemental practice sessions will be entirely student-run.  Students will download scripted emergency scenarios from their course web site.  One student will play the role of lead paramedic, another student will play the role of an EMT who assists the paramedic, while a third student will use the tablet to check off actions (e.g., Checked blood pressure) and to report the results of these actions (e.g., Blood pressure is 80/50).  All actions will be recorded in a log that will produce an automated debriefing; that is, feedback on student performance during the scenario.   Increased opportunities for students to practice skills during training could raise pass rates from paramedic programs and on certification exams.  Better-prepared paramedics will also increase patient safety.  Project findings might generalize to training of other healthcare providers such as doctors, nurses, and physician assistants.

This project will focus on the debriefing that typically follows a simulation-based training (SBT) exercise, when students reflect on their performance with feedback from a trained facilitator.  Although meta-reviews of SBT indicate that debriefing may be its most critical component, there is a dearth of research to guide debriefing practice.  This project will help to fill this void.  The research team will implement and compare the effectiveness of three approaches to automated debriefing.  One version will replicate the current state-of-the-art in automated debriefing, whereby students scroll through an event log with embedded textual feedback on their actions during the scenario.  This approach to debriefing does not follow a standardized protocol (script) for debriefing.  The second version follows a debriefing protocol whose acronym is DEBRIEF (for Define the debriefing rules; Explain the learning objectives; specify the performance Benchmarks; Review what was supposed to happen; Identify what actually happened; Examine why; and Formalize the take home points).  This version of automated debriefing simulates student self-guided debriefing.   The system will prompt the student to go through the DEBRIEF protocol steps but will not provide feedback.  The third version will simulate human facilitated debriefing.  Two automated agents, a facilitator and a peer, will support the student who played the role of lead paramedic during a practice scenario in carrying out a productive debriefing, according to DEBRIEF.  The main technological innovation will be development of methods to manage the interaction between these simulated agents (facilitator and peer) and the human paramedic student.  The project consists of three main phases.  First, to inform implementation of the agent facilitated debriefing system, the research team will observe and video record actual SBT scenarios and debriefings that take place during paramedic training at the University of Pittsburgh, Center for Emergency Medicine.  Second, the researchers will iteratively develop, field test, and refine each version of the debriefing system.  Third, the researchers will conduct a randomized controlled trial to compare the potential of these approaches to automated debriefing to improve psychomotor skills (e.g., cardiopulmonary resuscitation) and decision-making skills.  Study findings might generalize to simulation-based training of other healthcare professionals and to any field in which debriefing plays a major role in training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Project Goals

Simulation-based training (SBT) is vital for building healthcare students’ technical skills (e.g., performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation, establishing an intravenous injection) and non-technical skills, such as team coordination and clinical decision-making.  Debriefing is one of the most important elements of SBT, whereby the facilitator provides quality feedback on students’ performance which they can apply to future sessions.  However, many training programs face a shortage of experienced facilitators.  Consequently, students who need more practice than they get during regular course labs struggle or fail to acquire key skills, leaving them unprepared for real-world situations.  This project developed and tested a prototype of a tool called MedDbriefer that, when fully developed, will allow peers to gain supplemental SBT with expert-crafted scenarios and debriefings in any setting, at times that are convenient for them.  The system is web-based and runs on a tablet, rendering it portable and cost effective.

In developing MedDbriefer, we used emergency medical service (EMS) provider training—in particular, paramedic training—as our test domain.  MedDbriefer is designed to emulate facilitator-led training.  The tool allows students to observe their peers during SBT using only a tablet, without the need for high-fidelity manikins or computer-based simulators (e.g., Figure 1).   The peer observer (at right in Figure 1) uses the system’s checklists (e.g., Figure 2) to record the paramedic trainee’s (at left in Figure 1) verbalized and physical actions.  Clinical indicators such as blood pressure can change in response to these actions.  The tool tells the peer observer what indicators to call out when students request patient vital signs and other information.  For example, in Figure 2, the tool cues the observer to call out “shallow” (highlighted in yellow) when the student asks about the quality of the patient’s breathing.  It also displays prompts when the EMS team needs to provide further clinical information; for example, “What is the oxygen flow rate?” (Figure 2, upper right).  Most importantly, unlike other tools that have been used to support peer-to-peer simulation, MedDbriefer provides automated debriefings (e.g., Figure 3).

MedDbriefer also serves as a platform for research on simulation-based training.  For example, we used MedDbriefer to conduct a randomized controlled trial to compare two approaches to automated debriefing: a chronological walkthrough of students’ actions—color coded to highlight completed (green), missed or incorrectly performed (red) clinical actions (e.g., Figure 3)—versus an adaptation of a popular debriefing framework (DEBRIEF).  The chronological walkthrough is the standard debriefing approach implemented in computer-based simulation systems. 

Main Outcomes

Forty students who were enrolled in two types of paramedic programs—a Bachelor of Science in EMS (BS in EMS) program and a paramedic certificate program—at two sites, participated in the randomized trial.  Participants were randomly assigned to debriefing condition.   The study followed a pretest--intervention--posttest design.  The pretest consisted of an online test of clinical knowledge and two prehospital emergency care scenarios, without debriefings.  The training intervention followed the pretest and consisted of four scenarios with automated debriefings, structured chronologically or according to the DEBRIEF framework, based on participants’ assigned condition.  The posttest followed the training intervention and included a similar test of clinical knowledge, and similar EMS scenarios, as the pretest.  Participants filled out a feedback survey at the end of their session.

Results suggest that the two debriefing formats (chronological and DEBRIEF based) are equally effective in promoting significant gains in students’ clinical knowledge and decision-making ability.  Participants’ clinical knowledge posttest scores were significantly higher than their pretest scores, considering each condition separately and combined (e.g., Figure 4).  Similarly, subjects’ post-intervention scenario performance scores were significantly higher than their pre-intervention scenario performance scores, again considering each condition separately and both conditions combined (e.g., Figure 5).  No significant between-group differences were found for these outcome measures, and no interactions were observed between these measures and students’ gender or program type (e.g., Figure 6).

The system was very well-received.  On the user survey, students highlighted MedDbriefer’s potential to support supplemental peer-to-peer simulation and refresher training.

Significance

This project holds the potential to transform simulation-based training.  The findings from the randomized trial have implications for how simulation-based training should be conducted during live and automated SBT sessions.  They suggest that the standard chronological walk-through of students' scenario performance with feedback that is implemented in most computer-based simulation systems (e.g., Figure 3) may be just as effective as debriefings that are structured according to the DEBRIEF framework, and perhaps other debriefing frameworks.   Future research should investigate the extent to which these findings generalize to other frameworks, other EMS training programs, and other areas of healthcare (e.g., nurse and physician training).

When fully developed, MedDbriefer will provide a tool for pairs or small groups of EMS students to gain supplemental (out-of-lab) scenario-based practice.  Ultimately, it could be scaled to support peer-to-peer simulation across healthcare professions and other disciplines that require strong reasoning and decision-making skills.


Last Modified: 10/17/2024
Modified by: Sandra Katz

Project Goals


Simulation-based training (SBT) is vital for building healthcare students technical skills (e.g., performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation, establishing an intravenous injection) and non-technical skills, such as team coordination and clinical decision-making. Debriefing is one of the most important elements of SBT, whereby the facilitator provides quality feedback on students performance which they can apply to future sessions. However, many training programs face a shortage of experienced facilitators. Consequently, students who need more practice than they get during regular course labs struggle or fail to acquire key skills, leaving them unprepared for real-world situations. This project developed and tested a prototype of a tool called MedDbriefer that, when fully developed, will allow peers to gain supplemental SBT with expert-crafted scenarios and debriefings in any setting, at times that are convenient for them. The system is web-based and runs on a tablet, rendering it portable and cost effective.


In developing MedDbriefer, we used emergency medical service (EMS) provider trainingin particular, paramedic trainingas our test domain. MedDbriefer is designed to emulate facilitator-led training. The tool allows students to observe their peers during SBT using only a tablet, without the need for high-fidelity manikins or computer-based simulators (e.g., Figure 1). The peer observer (at right in Figure 1) uses the systems checklists (e.g., Figure 2) to record the paramedic trainees (at left in Figure 1) verbalized and physical actions. Clinical indicators such as blood pressure can change in response to these actions. The tool tells the peer observer what indicators to call out when students request patient vital signs and other information. For example, in Figure 2, the tool cues the observer to call out shallow (highlighted in yellow) when the student asks about the quality of the patients breathing. It also displays prompts when the EMS team needs to provide further clinical information; for example, What is the oxygen flow rate? (Figure 2, upper right). Most importantly, unlike other tools that have been used to support peer-to-peer simulation, MedDbriefer provides automated debriefings (e.g., Figure 3).


MedDbriefer also serves as a platform for research on simulation-based training. For example, we used MedDbriefer to conduct a randomized controlled trial to compare two approaches to automated debriefing: a chronological walkthrough of students actionscolor coded to highlight completed (green), missed or incorrectly performed (red) clinical actions (e.g., Figure 3)versus an adaptation of a popular debriefing framework (DEBRIEF). The chronological walkthrough is the standard debriefing approach implemented in computer-based simulation systems.


Main Outcomes


Forty students who were enrolled in two types of paramedic programsa Bachelor of Science in EMS (BS in EMS) program and a paramedic certificate programat two sites, participated in the randomized trial. The pretest consisted of an online test of clinical knowledge and two prehospital emergency care scenarios, without debriefings. The training intervention followed the pretest and consisted of four scenarios with automated debriefings, structured chronologically or according to the DEBRIEF framework, based on participants assigned condition. The posttest followed the training intervention and included a similar test of clinical knowledge, and similar EMS scenarios, as the pretest. Participants filled out a feedback survey at the end of their session.


Results suggest that the two debriefing formats (chronological and DEBRIEF based) are equally effective in promoting significant gains in students clinical knowledge and decision-making ability. Participants clinical knowledge posttest scores were significantly higher than their pretest scores, considering each condition separately and combined (e.g., Figure 4). Similarly, subjects post-intervention scenario performance scores were significantly higher than their pre-intervention scenario performance scores, again considering each condition separately and both conditions combined (e.g., Figure 5). No significant between-group differences were found for these outcome measures, and no interactions were observed between these measures and students gender or program type (e.g., Figure 6).


The system was very well-received. On the user survey, students highlighted MedDbriefers potential to support supplemental peer-to-peer simulation and refresher training.


Significance


This project holds the potential to transform simulation-based training. The findings from the randomized trial have implications for how simulation-based training should be conducted during live and automated SBT sessions. They suggest that the standard chronological walk-through of students' scenario performance with feedback that is implemented in most computer-based simulation systems (e.g., Figure 3) may be just as effective as debriefings that are structured according to the DEBRIEF framework, and perhaps other debriefing frameworks. Future research should investigate the extent to which these findings generalize to other frameworks, other EMS training programs, and other areas of healthcare (e.g., nurse and physician training).


When fully developed, MedDbriefer will provide a tool for pairs or small groups of EMS students to gain supplemental (out-of-lab) scenario-based practice. Ultimately, it could be scaled to support peer-to-peer simulation across healthcare professions and other disciplines that require strong reasoning and decision-making skills.
